sen.j: 岩佐 又兵衛（いわさ またべえ、 天正6年（1578年） - 慶安3年6月22日 (旧暦)（1650年7月20日）は、江戸時代初期の絵師。
sen.e: Matabe IWASA (1578-July 20, 1650) was a painter in the early Edo period.
Matabe IWASA (1578-July 20, 1650) was a painter in the early Edo period.
Matabe IWASA (1578-July 20, 1650) was a painter in the early Edo period.

sen.j: 又兵衛は通称で、諱は勝以（かつもち）。
sen.e: Matabe was his common name and his real name was Katsumochi.
Matabe was his common name and his real name was Katsumochi.
Matabe was his common name and his real name was Katsumochi.

sen.j: 略歴
sen.e: Brief Personal History
Brief Personal History
Brief Personal History

sen.j: 摂津国河辺郡伊丹（現在の兵庫県伊丹市伊丹）の有岡城主荒木村重の子として生まれる。
sen.e: He was born as a son of the lord of Arioka-jo Castle in Itami, Kawabe District, Settsu Province (now Itami, Itami City, Hyogo Prefecture), Murashige ARAKI.
He was born as a son of the lord of Arioka-jo Castle in Itami, Kawabe County, Settsu Province (now Itami, Itami City, Hyogo Prefecture), Murashige ARAKI.
sen.cmt: Kawabe District→Kawabe Countyに修正しました。
sen.e: He was born as a son of the lord of Arioka-jo Castle in Itami, Kawabe County, Settsu Province (now Itami, Itami City, Hyogo Prefecture), Murashige ARAKI.

sen.j: 誕生の翌年、村重は織田信長に反逆を企て（有岡城の戦い）、失敗。
sen.e: In the following year after his birth, Murashige attempted to rebel against Nobunaga ODA (the battle of Arioka-jo Castle) and failed.
In the following year after his birth, Murashige attempted to rebel against Nobunaga ODA (the Battle of Arioka-jo Castle) and failed.
sen.cmt: the Battle of Arioka-jo Castleとしました。
sen.e: In the following year after his birth, Murashige attempted to rebel against Nobunaga ODA (the Battle of Arioka-jo Castle) and failed.

sen.j: 落城に際して荒木一族はそのほとんどが斬殺されるが、数え年2歳の又兵衛は乳母に救い出され、石山本願寺に保護されて、母方の「岩佐」姓を名乗るようになる。
sen.e: When the castle fell, most members of the Araki family were killed, but Matabe, who was in his second year, was saved by his nanny and sheltered in Ishiyama Hongan-ji Temple, and then came to use his mother's family name, IWASA, as his family name.

When the castle fell, most members of the Araki family were killed, but Matabe, who was in his second year, was saved by his nanny and sheltered in Ishiyama Hongan-ji Temple, and then came to use his mother's family name, IWASA, as his family name.

When the castle fell, most members of the Araki family were killed, but Matabe, who was in his second year, was saved by his nanny and sheltered in Ishiyama Hongan-ji Temple, and then came to use his mother's family name, IWASA, as his family name.

sen.j: 40歳のころ北庄（現福井市）に移住し、同地に20余年留まった後、江戸に移り住み、そこで波乱に満ちた生涯を終える。
sen.e: At the age of 40, he moved to Kitanosho (now Hukui City) and stayed there for more than twenty years, and then moved to Edo, where he finished his life full of ups and downs.
At the age of 40, he moved to Kitanosho (now Fukui City) and stayed there for more than twenty years, and then moved to Edo, where he finished his life full of ups and downs.
At the age of 40, he moved to Kitanosho (now Fukui City) and stayed there for more than twenty years, and then moved to Edo, where he finished his life full of ups and downs.

sen.j: 絵の師匠は、村重の家臣を父に持つ狩野内膳という説があるがよくわかっていない。
sen.e: It is unknown who was his master of painting, although there is a theory that it was Naizen KANO, whose father was a vassal of Murashige.
It is unknown who was his master of painting, although there is a theory that it was Naizen KANO, whose father was a vassal of Murashige.
It is unknown who was his master of painting, although there is a theory that it was Naizen KANO, whose father was a vassal of Murashige.

sen.j: 俵屋宗達と並ぶ江戸初期を代表する大和絵絵師だが、様々な流派の絵を吸収し独自の様式を作り上げた。
sen.e: He was one of Yamato-e (traditional Japanese painting) painters who represent the early Edo period, equaling Sotatsu TAWARAYA, but he created his own unique style of painting by absorbing various schools' ways.

He was one of Yamato-e (traditional Japanese painting) painters representing the early Edo period, equaling Sotatsu TAWARAYA, but he created his own unique style of painting by absorbing various schools' ways.

He was one of Yamato-e (traditional Japanese painting) painters representing the early Edo period, equaling Sotatsu TAWARAYA, but he created his own unique style of painting by absorbing various schools' ways.

sen.j: 今では分割されてしまったが、『金谷屏風』には和漢の画題と画技が見事に融合しており、その成果を見ることが出来る。
sen.e: In "Kanaya Screen", which had been divided into several pieces by now, the subjects of painting and techniques from Chinese and Japanese classics were beautifully fused, and viewers can see the fruits of his style.
sen.cmt: そのまま訳すとわかりづらくなると思ったので、「その成果を見る」の主語に「viewers」、「その」の部分に「彼の様式の」を補いました。
sen.e: In the "Kanaya Screen," which had been divided into several pieces by now, the subjects of painting and techniques from Chinese and Japanese classics were beautifully fused, and viewers can see the fruits of his style.
sen.cmt: theを追加、全角クォーテーションを半角に修正、カンマの位置を移動しました。
sen.e: In the "Kanaya Screen," which had been divided into several pieces by now, the subjects of painting and techniques from Chinese and Japanese classics were beautifully fused, and viewers can see the fruits of his style.

sen.j: 人物表現にもっとも又兵衛の特色が現れ、たくましい肉体を持ち、バランスを失するほど極端な動きを強調する。
sen.e: The distinctive feature of Matabe's painting can be seen best in the representation of people; they have strongly-built bodies and their movements are extremely emphasized, which could almost disturb a balance.

The distinctive feature of Matabe's painting can be seen best in the representation of people; they have strongly-built bodies and their movements are extremely emphasized, which could almost disturb a balance.

The distinctive feature of Matabe's painting can be seen best in the representation of people; they have strongly-built bodies and their movements are extremely emphasized, which could almost disturb a balance.

sen.j: 相貌は豊かな頬と長い顎を持ち「豊頬長頤」と形容される。
sen.e: They have rich cheeks and long jaws, so their looks are described '豊頬長頤 (rich cheeks and long jaws)'.
They have rich cheeks and long jaws, so their looks are described '豊頬長頤' (rich cheeks and long jaws).
sen.cmt: 全角クォーテーションを半角に修正、位置を移動しました。
sen.e: They have rich cheeks and long jaws, so their looks are described '豊頬長頤' (rich cheeks and long jaws).

sen.j: 劇的なタッチとエネルギッシュな表現が特色のその作品はしばしば浮世絵の源流といわれる。
sen.e: It is frequently said that his works, whose distinctive features are his dramatic touch and energetic representation, are the origin of Ukiyoe (Japanese woodblock prints).
It is frequently said that his works, whose distinctive features are his dramatic touch and energetic representation, are the origin of Ukiyoe (Japanese woodblock prints).
It is frequently said that his works, whose distinctive features are his dramatic touch and energetic representation, are the origin of Ukiyoe (Japanese woodblock prints).

sen.j: 歌舞伎や文楽の人気演目である「傾城反魂香」の主人公「吃又」こと浮世又兵衛とモデルとされる。
sen.e: He is said to be a model of 'Domomata', or also called Matabe UKIYO, who is the main character of 'Keisei Hangonko,'which is a popular program in kabuki (Japanese traditional performing art) or bunraku (the traditional Japanese puppet theater).

He is said to be a model of 'Domomata,' or also called Matabe UKIYO, who is the main character of 'Keisei Hangonko,' which is a popular program in kabuki (Japanese traditional performing art) or bunraku (the traditional Japanese puppet theater).
sen.cmt: 全角クォーテーションを半角に修正、位置を移動、スペース追加しました。
sen.e: He is said to be a model of 'Domomata,' or also called Matabe UKIYO, who is the main character of 'Keisei Hangonko,' which is a popular program in kabuki (Japanese traditional performing art) or bunraku (the traditional Japanese puppet theater).

sen.j: 「又兵衛前派」の作との意見もあるが、今日では又兵衛自身が制作に関与したとの説が有力
sen.e: There is a theory that it is a work produced by 'previous-Matabe schools', but today the theory that Matabe himself was involved in the production of this work is more strong.
There is a theory that it is a work produced by 'previous-Matabe schools,' but today the theory that Matabe himself was involved in the production of this work is widely accepted.
sen.cmt: 全角クォーテーションを半角に修正、カンマの位置を移動、is more strong→is widely acceptedとしました。
sen.e: There is a theory that it is a work produced by 'previous-Matabe schools,' but today the theory that Matabe himself was involved in the production of this work is widely accepted.
